segments.text: I was born in Natchez, Mississippi, where the old South still is, November the 3rd, 1893, in Arlington Heights.
Can you tell us about your parents and your early years?
My mother died at the age of three, my age of three, and I was raised by my grandparents and my aunt in Natchez, Mississippi.
I attended the public schools and the cathedral Catholic school run by the Brothers of Sacred Heart, and they were tough.
While coming up in Natchez, you know that is the antebellum south.
A lot of things happened there.
For instance, Aaron Bull was concealed in 1807 in Windy Hill, Maine, after he killed Alexander Hamilton.
So we were raised in a history of traditions.
Every home, old home in Natchez, had some meaning in the historical part of our country.
In Natchez, outside of, not too far from there, was the Jefferson Military College, which was attended at one time by Jefferson Davis.
I saw that school grow, and I saw LSU play there many, many years ago as a child.

In the city of Natchez, there were a lot of Confederate veterans, and as a child, I'd listen to their tales, and from them, I learned the word, patria, that your country comes first, and you come next.
There were two National Guard companies in Natchez.
And every time then I'd get a chance, I'd go down there and watch them drill.
I always wanted to be in the military.
After finishing the cathedral school, I had a brother over here in Houston who had some friends connected with the Publishers Department of Texas A&M College and Fort Worth Star-Telegram.
And they prevailed on him to have me, his little brother, come over here to Texas A&M.

But in the meantime, old my uncle's store was a lawyer by the name of Lem Connor, who always represented the Honorable John Sharp Williams, the learned senator from Mississippi, who graduated from Heidelberg and the University of Virginia, who had farms down in Yazoo City.

I heard him tell Mr. Conner that he had sent his kid, his boy, John Sharp Williams, Jr., to every school in the country, and he couldn't get along, so he finally sent him to Texas A&M College, where the Honorable Jefferson Davis was offered the presidency of.
So I thought in my mind that was a good deal when my brother talked about Texas A&M College.
I had some knowledge of where I was going.
I entered Antietam College at the age of 16, having to take the entrance examination and ended with the class of 14.
I was assigned to Company B, 1st Battalion.
What was your dad's?
Could you tell me about your dad?
Your father?
Yes, I did.
I didn't put that.
My father You told me about your mother, but you didn't say anything about your father.
Yeah, well, my father was a fisherman and made his living down around Boris, Louisiana.
And, of course, when my mother died, he married again and he raised another family.
And then they were in the oyster business down there.
I saw my father only twice from infancy.
Once, when I was going to World War I, my brother insisted I ought to see my dad, so I went on down the Mississippi River to a place called Burris, went across to Ostraka, where he was, and saw him.
And the train on the other side was fixing to leave, because it wasn't going to stay a bit long when I go back across the river, so I saw him only
only for a short while.
My brother insisted I might get killed and I ought to see my dad as I grew up when I was grown.
But I did see my father after that.
My father died at the age of 90-something.
He fell.
He cut his head on an axe during a storm at Ostraca, which is across from Burris.
And they took him down to New Orleans on a launch.
But by the time he'd arrived in New Orleans, he'd lost so much blood, poor fella died.
Could you tell me more about your education before you got to Texas A&M?
I told you I finished it.
I went to public schools and the cathedral school run by the Brothers of the Sacred Heart.
Okay, and what were your favorite subjects?
History.
History, good.
I had witnessed and also the Honorable William Howard Taft came down the Mississippi River.
Really?
as President of the United States.
And in Natchez, there are three bluffs.
And one bluff is close to Rosalie, which is an old antebellum home, which was the headquarters of General Grant.
And that morning, the Honorable Charles F. Engle, one of the landed young lawyers of Natchez, in his morning coat, introduced the President of the United States.
And I said to myself, someday, if I could be a lawyer,
Like him, I would be very happy.
All right.
So that's why you wanted to become a lawyer?
Well, I didn't become a lawyer until later.
I know it.
All right.
Well, anyhow, so we were steeped in tradition.
And every kid knew what every home meant and how long it had been there and all of that.
And the people over there are raising their children the same way right now.
The, uh,
At Texas A&M, I was on probation the biggest part of the time.
Why was that?
Well, because I came from a school out of the state, and that is the first year I was on probation.
And I got along all right and was doing well until I went out on a strike in whatever year, 1913, and I made a great mistake because they changed...
from three times to two times.
And I was out of school some 35, 40 days with the rest of the people.
And in that, I learned in life not to strike anything but matches.
Now, why did you strike?
The strike was caused on by an investigation of hazing over in D Company by one of the Forsyth brothers.
And there was 22 people canned, one of them which was a 32nd degree mason.
And the other was we had the meningitis scare.
And we were assembled in the chapel and told not to worry, not to congregate, not to stay apart, and that we would escape any danger of the disease.
But while we were there in the hall, two days prior to that time,
A young man by the name of A.W.
Coons died.
Well, they thought he died with meningitis, but in testing the serum in his spine, they found out they were mistaken.
But this funny incident happened while they were telling us to be calm and quiet.
There was a fellow by the name of Pat Crown from Waco.
He froze up right quick like he had meningitis, and everybody ran out of every window, every door, and everything else out of there.
And that evening caught me in a strike due to the fact we had one doctor and two nurses in about 15 beds at that hospital.
So that brought on a strike, which was wrong, of course, known as the 466 Club.
In my estimate, that's 466 fools, which I was one of them.
Because I had to pay for that, because when it changed from three times to two times, there was no way I could make up my work, and I finally graduated in 1915.
Cut it off.
Cut it off.
They had to raise some money for the track team or whatever it was, so they put on a minstrel down at the athletic field.
And I doubled in that.
I did a blackface as Dr. Ball.
And I was such a hit that they thought I'd make a pretty good candidate

for Yale leader that year so later on I was made a Yale leader that next following year and I was assistant but my chief Yale leader wanted to play football and I had to act as chief all during that time and of course as a senior I was the head Yale leader.
I remember well that I was taking public speaking in my senior year and Dr. Bressler never did call on me the whole time that I was in his class.
I asked him why and he said he'd been out to Yale practice and he didn't want to waste time in class.
He was convinced I could make the public speech.
As a Yale leader I had many woes at Texas A&M College.
Dr. Bazell was down there and he was a freshman president from came down there from CIA and he had different ideas about many things.
With old Yale practice we were at the old bandstand and
Somebody must have got word back to him, because everything that I said or did related back to him, and the next morning I would see the order to come to class to have me go before the president.
In one instant, Doc Wiesel says to me, he says, do you see all these telegrams and letters?
I read a few of them, and the letters all said I sent my son to Texas A&M College to get an education not to travel over the state.
And I understand that they're going to Dallas, San Antonio, Fort Worth, Houston, Waco.
Dr. Bezell said, did you say that?
I said, we might go.
We might go to these places.
I didn't say we were going.
He said, you be careful what you say out there at that yell practice because it all goes back to the parents.
At another time, he called me.
We had a yell called hidey-tidey, tiey-a-didey, flim-flam.
A lot of times the kids would yell it and they'd use some curse words.
Gee damn varsity.
So Dr. Bazell got me up on that and told me to eliminate that yell.
I tried to explain to him that I didn't tell them to do that.
They'd do that themselves.
He would have me up every now and then to tone me down and find out what was going on at Yale practice.
Somebody told him this, some parent wrote this, that, and the other.
However, I struggled through the year and was never put on a report or kicked out of school for my activity as a Yale leader.
What kind of man did you think he was?
I thought Dr. Brazell was a fine man, but I hated to see the Board of Regents of A&M College
go to a girls' school and bring a president down there from the CIA.

He was a high religious man, which I had no objection to, but he made hypocrites out of a lot of those professors, because I remember well Gilbert Allen Giesch, who was a drunkard off the Philadelphia Ledger who taught freehand drawing, you had him carrying the Bible.
Really?
And a lot of kids would join his Bible class just in order to get favors.
At that time, you know, A&M College, of course, was an undersecretary, and everybody had to attend chapel on Sunday mornings.
The Jews were excused, and Catholics who would agree to go to Mass in the brine could go to Mass and not go to chapel.
But there was a trick in that, too.
There was a senior there at this Mass who always would check in and out, so you...
You couldn't evade going out of the church or the chapel.
While I was a senior there, or a junior, I forget, we organized the Newman Club, which is a Catholic club in Lorneville.
Last week or ten days, Father Matt called me from Bryan, saying that he had looked into Longhorn and found out that

I was one of the organizers of the Newman Club at Texas A&M College, and that he was a chaplain up there, and that they have 9,000 or more practicing Catholics due to the fact they thought of the Newman Club, which is a going concern at A&M College.
Cut.
I love my professors.
I had Dr. Francis in veterinary and agronomy.
And I had a Dr. Kiblin, economics.
Well, can you tell me a little bit about Mark Francis, Dr. Mark Francis?
What did you think of him?
Dr. Francis and I were very good friends.
And when I promoted, when I moved out of Tentrow and moved over to, finally to Goodman Hall, I would see Dr. Francis on the campus, and his son was a classmate of mine, Beb.
And we'd stop and talk a little bit.
So one day Dr. Francis told me, he says, what do you know, Vic?
Somebody hit me on the back and said, Jesus Christ, is that you?
And Dr. Francis told me then, he says, you know, I'm deaf.
And it's a great blessing to be deaf.
He says, I don't have to hear a whole lot of H.S.
from a lot of people.
Dr. Francis was lecturing one day and
There was a young man named Cogshill who had a hearing aid on, and Dr. Francis stopped his class in a minute, and he ran up the ramp and says, Say, can you hear out of that damn thing?
And the fellow shook his head.
So Dr. Francis says, Well, why don't you talk if you heard what I said?
So he went on down the ramp and continued his...
his lecture.

Another time, he saw, he stopped his class abruptly and went into the room, ante room, where we had cadavers and things, and took a bucket and he ran up the ramp with his bucket and he put it in front of this student and told him, says, look,
spit in this bucket, quit spitting out of that window.
Boy was chewing tobacco.
And he went back right on down nonchalantly and nobody cracked a smile and he went on with his lecture.
Dr. Marsteller was also a fine lecturer and we all had a lot of respect.
And once each year, Dr. Francis would devote one lecture.
I don't know whether it's been recorded, but it is great.
He always told the students, he'd give one lecture on life insurance, how to start an estate.
Why would he do that?
Why would he do that?
He did that because he loved young people.
He loved young people.
As you well know, Dr. Mark Francis came to Ohio State University, and you know his history about the Texas fever tick and all of that.
Well, what, tell me about his son.
What happened to his son?
His son, they graduated, he had two sons.
One of them died in class of 12, if you look in the book.
And Mark, and Bev was our classmate.
And his son graduated in veterinary medicine.
Well, they didn't give a degree in veterinary science in those days, and that class didn't start until the next year.
But he had some related degree to veterinary medicine.
The same way with his brother.
He was in the Army in World War I and II, and had a furniture store in Bryan.
His pictures, one of them there.
And he had a son, Mark Francis, Jr.,
But Bev is dead.
Practically all the members of my class in 1915 are dead, and about 18 still living, and none of them can move about.
I've been to these class reunions.
This year I couldn't go because of the conflict with the Marine Corps reunion in New Orleans.
It came the same day, so I couldn't go.
But I've been the only member there.
What were your favorite classes when you were at A&M?
I love veterinary medicine.
I like economics.
And of course, you don't have any history in your senior year, but we had history as freshmen.
And the chemistry came hard just like it did to everybody else, and I was no exception.
I had to take about four courses in chemistry.
And I failed the first course in chemistry, and I didn't realize it.
Oh, everybody was saying there's no disgrace to failing.
But I didn't realize before I could go another step further, I had to pass that first course in chemistry, which I wound up taking four courses in chemistry before I graduated.

I was wondering, when you came to A&M, when you decided to come to A&M, was that because you had talked to a lot of these old Confederate soldiers so much, and because you knew A&M as a military school?
Yeah, no, patria, the word patria.

I knew A&M was a military school, and what my brother, what John, the Honorable John Charles William had said about the school, and when he connected that with Jefferson Davis, I knew that's where I wanted to go to school.
Another favorite professor I had was Dr. Kibler, who taught economics.
And I well remember it was his senior year.
in the last class.
They'd been talking about social sciences, and there's a boy got up from Mason, Texas, by the name of Mason, and he said to Dr. Kibler, I've been listening to you talking about these social sciences.
Don't you have to have, don't you have to promote poverty for social sciences to be a success?
At that time, Dr. Kibler said, sit down, we'll meet some other time, or we never did meet any time.
However, those words from Mason
is brought up through the years and that we have all this social science, all this relief, all this food stamps, all this stuff that that young man was really thinking ahead.
Mason's brother was a Marine and he died of cancer.
He was in the 13th Marines in Brest, but anyhow, he died of cancer and I went out to see him there in the yard.
What about, I have another question, and that is,
When you were at A&M, did you think that you might want to be in the military as a career?
I didn't become a sergeant until in my junior year.
Not that I wasn't on the military, but I guess maybe I didn't fit in.
I never was a corporal, but I was made a sergeant in my junior year.
And then finally I was made a second lieutenant
in G Company, but I had to transfer.
I swapped with a boy named Gamble and got back in B Company, because that's where I was raised.
So I was a low-ranking second lieutenant in B Company.
And I always liked the military.
I never missed a drill.
I never missed a guard mount.
I never missed anything.
But however, there were other people more proficient in the military art than I was.
Of course, we had to take military science and tactics.
We had to study the campaigns of Marengo, Napoleonic campaigns, and all of that, which I don't know whether they do that today.
I want to say I was a shining star.
Now, were you in a position of leadership in the Corps?
Second lieutenant.
No.
Oh, okay.
Low rank and second lieutenant in B Company.
The lowest ranking.
I had one higher ranking second lieutenant myself.
That was it.
But your leadership was with the Yale, Yale leadership.
That's correct.
See, anyhow, I guess maybe they made me a...
But Dr. Zell did tell me when I graduated, he said, congratulations, I'm glad you're gone.
That's what he said?
I'm glad you're gone?
That's right.
Were you always considered a Hellraiser then?
Considered, yes, in a way, but I was always within the lines.
Of course, as a freshman, I was on a student labor role, and I worked down at the steam plant for 17 and a half cents an hour, and we'd unload the gondola one hour,
And then fire the boiler the next hour.
I well remember when I went down there to apply for the job at the steam plant.
Of course, you had to clear with the main office.
And this old man, Groupy, showed me how to fire a boiler.
He asked me if I'd ever fired a Nolson.
Well, there was a hole there about maybe 24 inches long and maybe 12 inches wide.
You're supposed to open this hole.
and take your scoop and turn your shovel and spread the cinders across the coils.

So he showed me how to do it one time and then next he had me do it again and I missed and he made me pick up all the coal and I did it and missed again the second time and finally I got the swing of turning my wrist to spread the coal.
I also had a job putting the mail on the train.
I got $10 a month for that.
I put the mail on a northbound train that came from Houston going to Dallas along about midnight, and then the one going south going to Houston from Dallas at 3 o'clock in the morning.
So along about quarter to 12, I'd leave my barracks and go down and get into the mail room.
I had to pull the mail truck out to where the mail car stopped, and that was it, and then pull the mail back into the mail room
So at the mail, the postmaster would get it.
I got ten dollars a month for that and every time I missed the mail I was fined ten dollars and several times I didn't make any money just because I overslept.
So it wasn't a very profitable job.
It wasn't a very profitable job.
Well in those days ten dollars went a long ways.
Another thing I had also, I was an agent from the M.C.
Lilly Company selling cap covers, and I'd blow everybody that had to have a cap cover.
Made a little profit on that.
What are cap covers?
The cap cover, your military cap.
Oh, okay, okay, the little, yeah, okay.
Yeah.
The little cover on top of your military hat.
Yeah, and those funny little hats you had on.
Sure, yeah, okay.
So, the real...
The real, I've been used to handling money and the first thing you know I was made chairman of the Thanksgiving Hop as a junior.
And I organized these people, I got collections from profs and everything else.
And financially it was a huge success.
And I published a report
Of course, we hit the professors and everybody else.
And I had a report from each company how much and gave them a report on the expenditures and all like that.
And they thought that was a great thing, but I didn't know anything about it because I'd had a little bookkeeping back in that cathedral school in Natchez.
I just thought that was the proper thing to do to render a report
and put it on the bulletin board.
Well, I did the wrong thing, because every time somebody about finances came up, they wanted to appoint me chairman of that committee.
Oh.
So you got a lot of experience there.
That's right.
Anyhow, so that brings me to graduation.
Well, I was happy to graduate.
The Honorable James Ferguson, the governor of Texas, handed me my diploma.
And I proceeded to Houston after that.
That would be in 1915, and they had nobody to ever offer me any jobs.
I have a question, though, about when you came to A&M, did you have any money to pay for it, or did you just find these jobs?
No, my brother advanced me the money.
Oh, good.
My brother advanced me the money, and I didn't want to impose on him too much because he was married, so I got my other money by working.
And when you graduated then in 1915, did you have some firm goals?
Did you want to go in the military?

Well, the thing about that, I went over there to the post office, and I thought I had a degree in agriculture, but in my mind what I did want to do, I had made a labor income report on the Harlem State Farm, and Mr. Blakely was a friend of mine, and I had in my mind if I could work at the Harlem Farms,
work for the government a couple of years, then go to the Harlem Farms and bring in mechanical farming on a large scale.
I learned a lot about farming.
Then I wanted to get out on my own as a large scale mechanical farmer.
Because just about that time, the hard part, people brought a tractor down to A&M.
There was nothing but one of these machines that you level ass for with, and it had spikes in it.
And they put a...
Professor Gee was a professor.
And they put a rail behind it, and they had a spike-toothed harrow and a disc harrow and a buster and so forth and so on.
But anyhow, so...
I go over there and take a look at the post office.
On the other side, they wanted a second lieutenant from the Marine Corps, and I looked at that just slightly.

My first experience with the Marine Corps was in Natchez, Mississippi, when the Mississippi came up the Mississippi River, and I saw the Marine Guard on there, and I thought their uniforms were beautiful, but I didn't know what it was.
When was that?
Do you remember when that was?
What?
When this first experience?
Is this before you went to A&M or after?
Okay, okay.
I was just digging back a little bit.
Okay, good.
And I saw this Marine Guard on there.
Okay, good.
On the U.S. Mississippi.
Came up the Mississippi River.
But anyhow, the...
But when you were at A&M, you weren't thinking about making a career out of the military then, were you?
No, I wasn't.
No, I was not.
But anyhow, the...
So I looked at the Department of Agriculture and I looked at the other, the second lieutenant of the Marine Corps, so I decided that maybe I'd try agriculture.
So I put in an application for that and I was given a job with the U.S. Department of Agriculture, the Bureau of Plant Industry, which was cooperating with the state of Texas.
in the cancer control, or citrus cancer control, and also a few of the plant diseases we were trying to control, pink boll one.
So I took that job and I said, they asked me a question, how many languages I could speak, and I said I could understand Italian and speak a little of it.
That's all I said, I didn't say I could read it or write it, which of course I was ashamed of, I should have learned to read it and write it.
but they didn't speak Italian in my home after my grandmother died in 1904.
But anyhow, so I finally got the job due to the fact that they had an Italian colony down at Dickinson in League City.
and Alta Loma and Hitchcock, and the inspectors were having trouble getting over the program to them, so I went on down there as assistant to one of the inspectors.
Well, I did a good job as assistant, so they made me the inspector.
I worked at that job down there for over a year, and I was about ready to be transferred.
My salary was $150 a month, and by that time I had bought a Ford,
and I was paying my brother back with a great advance on my education and then war was declared and in my brother's office in Houston the Marine recruiting office was on that same floor.
So one day the recruiting officer said to me he knew he had met me over at the press club and I was with
Bruce Mansfield, who was the son of Congressman Mansfield, and Mansfield was teaching descriptive geometry at A&M.
He was down there for the summer.
So, McCauley, well, anyhow, the war was declared, and I decided my own self.
I was told I had an exemption because we needed cotton to make gunpowder with and so forth and so on, but I had well remembered that what I wanted to do, so...
McCauley got us up to his office and said that we could be 2nd Lieutenant of the Marine Corps provided we'd go over to New Orleans and take the examination.
That our certification as to our education qualification would be substantiated by our degrees from Texas A&M College.
So I proceeded to New Orleans, Louisiana.
Bruce Mansfield and I went before a board and
passed the board and passed the physical and everything and was made a second lieutenant and before we were told to return home and in three days time we had proceed orders.
I had been in a little bit of disfavor at A&M about a matter that was questionable and I was told to stay off the campus.
What matter was that?
The distribution of it.
a paper called the court-martial put out by the class of 16.
I had distributed them and of course, being a yellow leader, everybody knew me and of course I was on report and that night at the dance.
What did this paper say?
Well, it was like the rip saw that they put out at the University of Virginia.
It said that Dr. Brazell's wife was going to examine the lingerie of all the girls before they go to the dance.
And the fictitious names of the editors were YMCA people and goody-goody boys like Penrose Metcalf and Whitey Moffat and all of that.
And then they called, they said something about, they called Dean Kyle, Edward Jackass Kyle, all in fun.
And so that night I was dancing, I was the sheriff of...
We said, Brad, this guy tapped me on the shoulder and says, I got a warrant for your arrest for criminal libel.
So I turned around and I said, what do I do next?
And by that time, a fellow by the name of Meredith James, whose father had a drug store in Bryan, he went to my barn.
Another fellow from out west Texas by the name of L.P. Jones, he went to my barn.
So I went back on my territory, intended to my business.
So I knew...
When war was declared, I knew whether to come to A&M College because I was told to stay off the campus.

So I knew whether to come back up there and ask for a application to be commissioned in the Army, but I'd always had a tender heart for the Marine Corps because I loved those blues and I'd read about the Marines at Santiago and I'd already read about the Marine history and all like that, so it didn't mean anything.
So...
So that's why you went in the Marines, though, instead of the Army?
I went to Marine Corps first, I had a love for the Marines.
As a child, I saw all those people coming up from Mississippi River, the Marine Guard, you know.
I got pictures of Mississippi right down in there right now.
Anyhow.
There's another thing that I wanted to ask you about the Corps.
And I was wondering what ways do you think the Corps helped you?
The Corps helped me.
If I hadn't been a second lieutenant in the Marine Corps, I never could have.
I mean, in A&M, I never could have made it in the Marine Corps.
Oh, why do you say that?
Because the things I learned at Texas A&M College, continual close order drill, continual discipline, continual guard mount, the honor system, and the comradeship,
Organization, leadership, that you learned at A&M College.
Although I wasn't such a big crowd, but I realized it all had to be.
That's what makes a good leader.
And practically all, I wasn't the only Aggie.
There were 22 of us went in the Marine Corps during that time, 22 Aggies.
And all of us had been in the Corps.
Not like today, you don't have to be in the Corps, but everybody had been in the Corps.
Had to be in the Corps because under the Smith-Lever Act, that's what they were supposed to seek, military science and tactics and agriculture and engineering art.
Well, I see right now they're bacheloring the act because they're not doing that.
Everybody ought to have two years of military service.
Was there any way, do you think, that the Corps might not have helped you, might have hindered you?
Never.
Never will I think that.

I was so proud to be a cadet at A&M College and when they gave me that sword and gave me that parchment the second lieutenant was hanging around, I was just so grateful I felt proud of even being a second lieutenant.
I was proud of being a sergeant.
Was there anything about the Corps that you did not like?
Not a thing.
Never.
I loved the leadership.
I admired all those people.
And after civil life, after all that, I can see back now what it did.
And when I see the people of A&M College have accomplished something, they've always had training and leadership which started at Texas A&M College.
So, in other words, you think the Corps helped you become a general?
You bet, I do.
I certainly do.
Because it taught you to be a leader?
I think it did.
I know it did.
Okay, okay, fine.
See, I know it did.
Mm-hmm.
And, uh...
The things I learned at A&M College about defense, I lived in a tent two years.
Well, it wasn't, that wasn't, it was tough.
I said to somebody, I lived in a tent two years, and he said, well, you're setting him once more on education, my bad.
Well, either he was that or else.
It was very unhandy.
My headquarters was up at Austin Hall, and I lived in tent 12.
It was 12 places from the flagpole.
And when you had guard mount, you had to go all the way up.
Dawson Hall, the details started there, instead of starting out in front of the main building, it started there.
But with all the hardships, all that discipline, I think in the Act of Life, the things you have to do, there's no easy way.
You take things step by step.
Same way with responsibility.
You start with a little responsibility, and you come with another and another.
Now... Now there's something else I'd like to ask you.
You must have dealt with a lot of officers
during your career that were either from Annapolis or from ROTC?
I'll get to that.
Okay, fine.
All right, now wait a minute.
Okay.
We were talking about... We were talking about the Corps.
We were talking about getting in the Marine Corps.
Yeah.
All right, well, when I had been home three days and I received receipt orders... Mm-hmm.

And I decided to go up to Texas A&M to tell my favorite professors goodbye, and the sergeants in the commandant's office, Sergeant Kenny, Sergeant Smart, and Sergeant Kenny Smart, and Holland, called him Satch, who incidentally had a son who graduated at West Point.
So when I arrived there, a young officer, I can't call his name right now, who was assistant commandant,
heard me back there talking to Sergeant Kenny and said to me, he says, your name Baraka?
Yes.
I said, well, did you get that letter?
I said, yes, I got that letter.
I was staying off this campus.
Yes, I did.
He says, but I says to him, Lieutenant, you don't know who you're talking to.
By that time, I told him, I says, you are talking to Second Lieutenant Victor A. Baraka, United States Marine Corps.
on the proceed orders.
I said, this is a land grant scholar and an instrumentality of the government and the Marine Corps and an instrumentality of the government and so you can't put me off this campus.
So he said, let me see your orders.
So I showed him my orders and when he saw that proceed, he knew that I was on duty to go and pay then.
He reached out his hand and congratulated me and said, I hope you get back alive.
That's true.
All right.
Now we're going to get...
So that was 1917, as soon as America went into the war.
That's correct.
Okay.
All right.
Now... What did I do with that?
Now, I'll give you briefly... Of course, I've got some pictures here.
I'm going to give you a copy of this.
Okay, good.
I said I commissioned second lieutenant in the Marine Corps, April 1970, and he completed the basic course, Marine Corps School, Quantico, Virginia.
Evidence.
Oh, really?
Nice picture.
These are the great-greats of the Marine Corps.
So this is officer training school here?
That's right.
Quantico, Virginia, 1917.
Ain't no bull here.
August.
Yeah, I am right there.
See me?
Yeah.
There's Brailford, one of the first Marines to get killed.
There's Gilfillan from up at Tyler.
Former commandants of the Marine Corps are all in this group.
Cates and them and all that.
It is.
That's a nice picture.
There's the Honorable, there's Drexel Biddle.
We don't mean much to you, but there's a family of Bailey Banks and Biddle in Philadelphia.
He stayed on active in the Marine Corps for free.
Biddle.
I know Biddle.
He taught us, he taught us.
I know the Biddle family.
You do.
He taught us the bayonet, the quake, the boxing.
In the Marine Corps, we had to run boxing.
I'll tell you about that.
Tell me about that.
Tell me about your basic training back in 1917.
All right, we'll go through it right quick.
The basic training in 19, as I showed you, in this officer battalion here, was broken down into companies A, B, C, and D, and I happened to be in B company again.
It was commanded by...
a son of a great-grand-nephew of General Robert E. Lee.
He was a very kind man.
We were issued 782 equipment, and we were barracks all together, organizing companies, and we trained very hard.
We all had classroom in the mornings.
We had
Then we had drill all day and half the night.
In that school we learned to do topography and I often thought when I had to take civil engineering one and two as a bug under the A&M, God, what the hell I ever needed that for.
But I knew I needed it later on at A&M when I took water conservation and making terraces.
I always did come in handy for me making contour maps because all they gave us was a plane table and a compass.
We had all kinds of real forced marches.
We had plenty of experience in the field.
We had banded fighting.
We had boxing.
And I well remember that old man Biddle, with his marches out,
and with right face around that, that was your opponent, all that on gloves.
And he said you had to learn to box before you could use a bayonet.

So he said, you got a bayonet, you hit a guy in the chest with a bayonet, you slash him over the head with your, I mean, with the butt of your rifle, butt him up in the breast, you slash him over the head with your rifle, and if your rifle breaks, you kick him in the nuts, or the cards, he said.
He also showed us how to use a knife and quake, and in those days, judo had just started.
That was all part of our training.

As I say, we learned signal work, semaphore, the Morse code, and we had all kinds of close order drills every day and tactics and problems and so forth and so on, besides building a trench city where the,
Butler Stadium is there in Quantico, Virginia today.
The termination of that school, I Did you think it was a good school?
I mean, did you think you learned a lot?
Did you learn a lot?
Sure learned a lot.
Did they prepare you?
I had learned to fire the range at A&M College, too.
And when they took me to the rifle range, of course I wasn't so hot, but the second day I was on the line,
Sergeant grabbed me and he says, the way you're going, you're not going to make exploits.
We want our officers to be exploits.
So I snapped in for three or four days there, and he put me on the line, and I made exploits.
This is all at Quantico, Virginia, the officer school.
How many Aggies were there in your class?
About 22.
About 22 Aggies.
Out of how many, about 100?
Were there about 100 there?
No, there wasn't any 100 there.
How many were there?
I would say there were about 12 of us in that class.
These other people, with their training, they didn't go to officer school.
Kids who had graduated in 1917, as you recall, were in ROTC.
So they took officers from the class of 15, 16, and the people in 17 had the preference because they were already in ROTC.
And whatever service they went in, they assigned them to active duty immediately.
I see.
I see.
See?
But in my school, there'd been people in ROTC, too.
I showed you that picture of those people.
But anyhow, I was assigned a duty at...
Charleston Navy Yard, I didn't get it in there, but for transportation to the West Indies.
I served as a big part of the war in the West Indies.
Virgin Islands, March 1918.
There you go.
You can take this.
Either one of you can take this.
All right.
Now what did you do there?
You were the post-treasurer?
I was disappointed, of course, that I didn't get overseas, but the Marine Corps had so many stations and the Army didn't want too many Marines overseas.
We didn't have but two regiments, 15th and 6th, and the 13th back at Brest on the General's button.
They didn't want any in the lines, but Marines did have three or four generals commanding Army divisions, which was General Lejeune and others.
So you were upset that you couldn't go and fight against Germany?
No.
But I went to West Indies.
And in the West Indies, you know, we were fighting bandits from Haiti and San Domingo and all those places, and this command here was part of it.
I don't understand, though.
Tell me, what do you mean you were fighting bandits?
You were keeping the peace?
Yeah, in Haiti and San Domingo.
Okay.
You see, this was all under the...
